text.author: Lyn Gardner
text.description: King's Head, LondonFrom the true story of the Liverpool fan who watched the 2005 Champions League final with Silvio Berlusconi, John Graham Davies has fashioned a lively if occasionally wearing one-man show, writes Lyn Gardner
text.title: Beating Berlusconi! | Theatre review

main.p: Istanbul, 25 May 2005, the Champions League final. Liverpool are playing like muppets, and are down 3-0 to AC Milan by half time. A devoted fan, Kenny, is so disgusted that he wanders away from his seat, gets lost in a maze of corridors and eventually finds himself in the AC Milan directors' box sitting next to the Italian prime minister, Silvio Berlusconi, and quaffing champagne.

From a 10-minute anecdote of something that really happened to a Liverpool fan, John Graham Davies has fashioned a lively one-man show that is an odyssey through 40 years of Liverpool life. Even for non-football fans, it's a punchy piece of good old-fashioned popular theatre that wears its passions and prejudices on its sleeve: Scousers good; Liverpool FC even better; Maggie Thatcher "a Nazi in a dress"; Manchester United "the crimson haemorrhoids". The partisanship does prove rather wearing for those of us without strong tribal loyalties, and inevitably the show packs less of a punch in N1 than it would playing to the crowd in its home city, where it has been a big success.

Though this is about the fever of the football fan, it is also a skimmed social history of Liverpool, through the riots of 1981 and the Thatcher years to the war in Iraq and the tragic events at Heysel and at Hillsborough. Kenny is a flawed everyman, unwittingly sitting on the sidelines of the events of history.

The show would be greatly improved if it lasted 90 minutes rather than going into extra time, and at a preview performance, Paul Duckworth – who plays dozens of roles with relish – hadn't yet pitched his performance to a small space. But although it may not be perfectly formed, it's a show with balls, in more ways than one.
